title.narrative: Att utveckla medlingsmetoder i civilrättsliga tvis
Developing mediation practices in civil disputes

description.narrative:
Europarådet har ansökt till Sida om finansiering av MSEK 9.930.000 för att genomföra "Projekt för att utveckla medlingsmetoder i civilrättsliga tvister i Turkiet" under perioden 2014-2016. Insatsens totala budget är MSEK 12.123.780, varav finansiering från Sida efterfrågas om MSEK 9.930.000 och resterande MSEK 2.193.780 finansieras av det turkiska justitieministeriet, som också är genomförandepart för hela insatsen.
Insatsen syftar till att bidra till att lösa problemet med effektiviteten i det turkiska rättsväsendet genom att sprida användningen av medling i civilrättsliga tvister, främst genom att skapa grunden för ett effektivt genomförande av medlingslagen. Insatsen syftar till att utveckla praktiska modeller, anpassade till Turkiet, och samtidigt integrera bästa praxis från internationella exempel, där så är möjligt. Insatsen kommer att utse pilotdomstolar för att uppmuntra användningen av medlingsinstrumentet och för att tillämpa bästa tillgängliga metoder samt använda gjorda erfarenheter i dessa pilotdomstar. Praxis ska sedan syfta till att förbättra existerande lagstiftning genom att producera rekommendationer som kan bidra till att föreslå lagförändringar om nödvändigt.
Ökad medvetenhet bland domare, advokater, civila organisationer och allmänheten kring medlingsinstrumentet och dess användning är ett annat delmoment av insatsen då medling är ett för Turkiet nytt instrument för juridisk konfliktlösning.

The intervention aims to contribute to solving the problem of efficiency of justice by spreading the use of mediation in civil disputes, principally by establishing the basis for the effective implementation of the Mediation Law. The project will develop practical models suited to Turkey, while integrating best practices from international examples where possible. The project will especially be useful in designating pilot courts to encourage the use of mediation and to employing the best practices and making use of lessons-learned in these pilot courthouses. Another way in which to address the problem will be to ensure a facilitating legislative environment by producing recommendations that may help amend the Law to this effect, as well as awareness raising among judges, lawyers, civil society organizations and members of the public.
The overall objective of the project is to improve the efficiency of justice by reducing the cost and time needed to resolve civil disputes through an effective implementation of mediation practices.

description.narrative: The main result of the projects were: - to strengthen the current legal framework on mediation; - to develop practical model for mediation practices through piloting in 32 civil courts in six jurisdictions; - to develop training curricula and set up a training scheme; - to increase public awareness on mediation process. The Project outcomes have greatly improved the capacity of mediation scheme in Turkey via legislative changes by ensuring relevant CEPEJ Guidelines were reflected. Amendments have been carried out in regard to the Mediation Law and Labour law. Mediation process became a pre-condition for case opening for labour disputes this was adopted in the Parliament one month before the end of the Project’s period of implementation. Enhancing the skills and knowledge of civil judges, staff of the Mediation Information Centres (MICs) in pilot courthouses as well as the mediators has led to increased judicial referrals to mediation as well as out-of-court mediation. It also strengthened the cooperation among judges, court staff, mediators and mediation associations and has raised awareness on the mediation process and enabled access to mediation procedures. Analysis of the current existing training programmes were conducted and new training programmes/curricula for basic mediation training for both trainers and trainees was developed. These reference training curricula are disseminated by the MoJ to the training institutions, based on CEPEJ tools and methodology, as well as CoE Committee of Ministers’ Recommendations on mediation. Training times have been extended for capacity improvement. A unified curricula is expected to allow better monitoring of the quality of mediators. A Public Awareness and Communication Strategy with the Project stakeholders to increase the public awareness was developed. The number of mediated cases from December 2014 to February 2016, both in judicial referral and out of court mediation, increased in the pilot jurisdictions from 25 (December 2014) to 13,470 (May 2017); the number of mediations has increased in pilot provinces by more than 14 times since beginning of the Project. A sustainability strategy was developed, with an Action Plan for the future five years for the MoJ to sustain and enrich the Project’s outcomes. A gender action plan study was carried out and incorporated to all activities and publications of the project. The Project team initiated a gender-specific work in particular for the training component and family mediation, paying special attention to gender-sensitive issues and using gender neutral vocabulary, in order to better empower both the parties in civil disputes.
